title: How to Build a Backyard Firepit

steps.title: Pick a spot and dig a hole.
steps.content: Pick a spot and dig a hole. The hole should be 1.5' deep and 5' wide. Get it as flat as possible on the bottom. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Set up your firebrick ring.
steps.content: Set up your firebrick ring. Buy a bunch of firebricks (used to line fireplaces). There should be enough that you can make a circle to your desired size with the bricks standing on their ends. Form the circle in the hole by standing the bricks on end and putting one next to the other. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Solidify the ring.
steps.content: Solidify the ring. Use concrete, cobb, clay, or other fire-resistant materials to join the bricks together into a solid, strong ring. Let this material dry completely before continuing. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Fill in the edges.
steps.content: Fill in the edges. Fill in any space outside the circle with dirt. This is so the ground leads right up to the top edge of the brick.

steps.title: Fill the center.
steps.content: Fill the center. Pour a layer of river rocks into the central pit. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add a decorative edge.
steps.content: Add a decorative edge. Get some paving stones or garden stones (the kind you usually use to make a path with) and use them to form a ring around the fire pit.

steps.title: Enjoy your pit!
steps.content: Enjoy your pit! Be careful not to let grass overgrow the stones and get too close to the fire.

steps.title: Select a spot for your pit.
steps.content: Select a spot for your pit. Choose a place that will provide room to walk around the fire, away from plants, fences, or any other kinds of flammable material. Consider the wind in your backyard and the way it will blow smoke from the fire. Also consider how many people will be enjoying the fire, a 6-foot buffer minimum is a good idea. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Dig a circular hole, 4-feet in diameter and 12-inches deep.
steps.content: Dig a circular hole, 4-feet in diameter and 12-inches deep.

steps.title: Using cement bricks, construct a 12-inch high wall around the pit.
steps.content: Using cement bricks, construct a 12-inch high wall around the pit. Leave about 2 inches (5.1 cm) between the bricks for air circulation.

steps.title: Lay down some concrete, the quick setting type.
steps.content: Lay down some concrete, the quick setting type. Cover most of the bottom of the pit, creating a small "dip" in the center where you can place newspaper and kindling. Sprinkle water on the concrete until it hardens to your satisfaction.

steps.title: Build the fire.
steps.content: Build the fire. Construct a tepee from kindling around the newspaper. Light the newspaper, and you're ready to go. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Feed the fire.
steps.content: Feed the fire. When the kindling gets going, start placing bigger pieces of wood around the shelf in a tepee shape. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Get curved pieces of garden edging.
steps.content: Get curved pieces of garden edging. These are sometimes referred to as tree rings. The edging will need to be made of stone, clay, or brick and can be scalloped or straight across the top. You will need to purchase 4 pieces of 14" inside diameter bricks and 6 pieces of 24" inside diameter bricks.

steps.title: Lay out the first layer.
steps.content: Lay out the first layer. Clear an appropriate area for your firepit and then lay out the first two 14" pieces to form a circle. Use three of the 24" to form a larger circle around the first one. You can use a bit of concrete to help the pieces stay together, if you want.

steps.title: Lay out the second layer.
steps.content: Lay out the second layer. Use the remaining pieces to set out the second layer, on top of the first. You can put a layer of concrete between the two stone layers, if you want to. If you use scalloped bricks, put the second layer upside down, so the scalloped edges are touching between the two layers.

steps.title: Fill with rocks.
steps.content: Fill with rocks. Fill the gap between the circles with river rocks until the brim is reached. Alternatively, you can fill it most of the way to full and then put down a thinner layer of more aesthetically pleasing rocks, like glass pebbles.

steps.title: Line the bottom.
steps.content: Line the bottom. Put a small layer of river rocks or other fire-friendly material in the bottom of the pit. Alternatively, you can find a grill bowl with the same diameter (or very slightly larger) as the central circle and place it there.

steps.title: Light your fire!
steps.content: Light your fire! Set up a wood fire in the central pit and enjoy your new fire pit. Put a circular grill surface over the hole to use it as an outdoor cooking pit!

steps.title: Check with your local authorities before lighting any kind of fire.
steps.content: Check with your local authorities before lighting any kind of fire. A fire in an open pit may be illegal in your area. [8] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source

steps.title: Be kind to your neighbors.
steps.content: Be kind to your neighbors. Check with them first and tell them you will reduce the smoke as much as possible. [9] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source

steps.title: Always extinguish the fire correctly.
steps.content: Always extinguish the fire correctly. [10] X Research source Don't just let the fire go out on its own. Ash and embers can remain hot and dangerous for a long time. Spread the coals around the bottom of the pit and douse them with water until all smoke and steam has disappeared.
